- Time-evolution operator

Time-evolution operator ğ‘ˆ(ğ‘¡)

âˆ£Ïˆ(t)âŸ©=U^(t)âˆ£Ïˆ(0)âŸ©|\psi(t)\rangle=\widehat{U}(t)|\psi(0)\rangleâˆ£Ïˆ(t)âŸ©=U(t)âˆ£Ïˆ(0)âŸ©

U^(t)\widehat{U}(t)U(t) is Hermitian operator.

In order for probability to be conserved as time evolves,

âŸ¨Ïˆ(t)âˆ£Ïˆ(t)âŸ©=âŸ¨Ïˆ(0)âˆ£U^â€ (t)U^(t)âˆ£Ïˆ(0)âŸ©=âŸ¨Ïˆ(0)âˆ£Ïˆ(0)âŸ©\begin{aligned}\langle\psi(t) | \psi(t)\rangle &=\left\langle\psi(0)\left|\widehat{U}^{\dagger}(t) \widehat{U}(t)\right| \psi(0)\right\rangle \\ &=\langle\psi(0) | \psi(0)\rangle \end{aligned}âŸ¨Ïˆ(t)âˆ£Ïˆ(t)âŸ©â€‹=âŸ¨Ïˆ(0)âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹Uâ€ (t)U(t)âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹Ïˆ(0)âŸ©=âŸ¨Ïˆ(0)âˆ£Ïˆ(0)âŸ©â€‹

And consequently the operator U^(t)\widehat{U}(t)U(t) must be unitary:

U^â€ (t)U^(t)=1\widehat{U}^{\dagger}(t) \widehat{U}(t)=1Uâ€ (t)U(t)=1

The Hamiltonian H^\widehat{H}H, the energy operator, enters as the generator of time translations through the infinitesimal time-evolution operator:

U^(dt)=1âˆ’iâ„H^dt\widehat{U}(d t)=1-\frac{i}{\hbar} \widehat{H} d tU(dt)=1âˆ’â„iâ€‹Hdt

The time-evolution operator obeys the differential equation

H^(t)U^(t)=iâ„ddtU^(t)\hat{H}(t) \widehat{U}(t)=i \hbar \frac{d}{d t} \widehat{U}(t)H^(t)U(t)=iâ„dtdâ€‹U(t)

leading to the Schrodinger equation:

H^âˆ£Ïˆ(t)âŸ©=iâ„ddtâˆ£Ïˆ(t)âŸ©\widehat{H}|\psi(t)\rangle= i \hbar \frac{d}{d t}|\psi(t)\rangleHâˆ£Ïˆ(t)âŸ©=iâ„dtdâ€‹âˆ£Ïˆ(t)âŸ©

A particularly useful solution to (*) occurs when the Hamiltonian is independent of time, in which case the time-development operator is given by

U^(t)=eâˆ’iEt/â„\widehat{U}(t)=e^{-i E t / \hbar}U(t)=eâˆ’iEt/â„

The action of the time-development operator on an energy eigenstate âˆ£EâŸ©|E\rangleâˆ£EâŸ© is given by

eâˆ’iH^t/â„âˆ£EâŸ©=eâˆ’iEt/â„âˆ£EâŸ©e^{-i \hat{H} t / \hbar}|E\rangle= e^{-i E t / \hbar}|E\rangleeâˆ’iH^t/â„âˆ£EâŸ©=eâˆ’iEt/â„âˆ£EâŸ©

Showing that a single energy eigenstate just picks up an overall phase as time evolves and is therefore a stationary state.

Superposition of energy eigenstates

  • Time evolution for a state operator âˆ£Ïˆ(t)âŸ©|\psi(t)\rangleâˆ£Ïˆ(t)âŸ©
âˆ£Ïˆ(0)âŸ©=âˆ‘nâˆ£EnâŸ©âŸ¨Enâˆ£Ïˆ(0)âŸ©|\psi(0)\rangle=\sum_{n}\left|E_{n}\right\rangle\left\langle E_{n} | \psi(0)\right\rangleâˆ£Ïˆ(0)âŸ©=nâˆ‘â€‹âˆ£Enâ€‹âŸ©âŸ¨Enâ€‹âˆ£Ïˆ(0)âŸ©

is given by

âˆ£Ïˆ(t)âŸ©=eâˆ’iB^t/â„âˆ‘nâˆ£EnâŸ©âŸ¨Enâˆ£Ïˆ(0)âŸ©=âˆ‘neâˆ’iEnt/â„âˆ£EnâŸ©âŸ¨Enâˆ£Ïˆ(0)âŸ©\begin{aligned}|\psi(t)\rangle &= e^{-i \widehat{B} t / \hbar} \sum_{n}\left|E_{n}\right\rangle\left\langle E_{n} | \psi(0)\right\rangle \\ &=\sum_{n} e^{-i E_{n} t / \hbar}\left|E_{n}\right\rangle\left\langle E_{n} | \psi(0)\right\rangle \end{aligned}âˆ£Ïˆ(t)âŸ©â€‹=eâˆ’iBt/â„nâˆ‘â€‹âˆ£Enâ€‹âŸ©âŸ¨Enâ€‹âˆ£Ïˆ(0)âŸ©=nâˆ‘â€‹eâˆ’iEnâ€‹t/â„âˆ£Enâ€‹âŸ©âŸ¨Enâ€‹âˆ£Ïˆ(0)âŸ©â€‹

When the superposition involves states with different energies, the relative phase between the energy eigenstates changes with time. The time in this case satisfies

Î”EÎ”tâ‰¥â„2\Delta E \Delta t \geq \frac{\hbar}{2}Î”EÎ”tâ‰¥2â„â€‹

where âˆ†ğ¸ is the usual uncertainty in energy for the state âˆ£ÏˆâŸ©|\psi\rangleâˆ£ÏˆâŸ©.

  • Suppose two stationary states,
Î¨1(x,t)=Ïˆ1eâˆ’iÏ‰1tÂ andÂ Î¨2(x,t)=Ïˆ2eâˆ’iÏ‰2t\Psi_{1}(x, t)=\psi_{1} e^{-i \omega_{1} t} \text { and } \Psi_{2}(x, t)=\psi_{2} e^{-i \omega_{2} t}Î¨1â€‹(x,t)=Ïˆ1â€‹eâˆ’iÏ‰1â€‹tÂ andÂ Î¨2â€‹(x,t)=Ïˆ2â€‹eâˆ’iÏ‰2â€‹t

where â„Ï‰1=E1\hbar \omega_{1}=E_{1}â„Ï‰1â€‹=E1â€‹ and â„Ï‰2=E2\hbar \omega_{2}=E_{2}â„Ï‰2â€‹=E2â€‹ are the corresponding energies.

To be definite, we could consider Ïˆ1\psi_{1}Ïˆ1â€‹ and Ïˆ2\psi_{2}Ïˆ2â€‹ to be the lowest two wave functions of the finite potential well with n=1 and 2. The linear combination of these two states,

Î¨(x,t)=c1Î¨1(x,t)+c2Î¨2(x,t)\Psi(x, t)=c_{1} \Psi_{1}(x, t)+c_{2} \Psi_{2}(x, t)Î¨(x,t)=c1â€‹Î¨1â€‹(x,t)+c2â€‹Î¨2â€‹(x,t)

for any two imaginary numbers c1c_{1}c1â€‹ and c2c_{2}c2â€‹.

  • In the time-dependent Schrodinger equation:
iâ„âˆ‚âˆ‚tÎ¨(x,t)=c1â„âˆ‚âˆ‚tÎ¨1(x,t)+c2â„âˆ‚âˆ‚tÎ¨2(x,t)=c1(âˆ’â„22mâˆ‚2âˆ‚x2+U(x))Î¨1(x,t)+c2(âˆ’â„22mâˆ‚2âˆ‚x2+U(x))Î¨2(x,t)=(âˆ’â„22mâˆ‚2âˆ‚x2+U(x))Î¨(x,t)\begin{aligned} i \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \Psi(x, t) &=c_{1} \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \Psi_{1}(x, t)+c_{2} \hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \Psi_{2}(x, t) \\ &=c_{1}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}+U(x)\right) \Psi_{1}(x, t)+c_{2}\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}+U(x)\right) \Psi_{2}(x, t) \\ &=\left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2 m} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{2}}+U(x)\right) \Psi(x, t) \end{aligned}iâ„âˆ‚tâˆ‚â€‹Î¨(x,t)â€‹=c1â€‹â„âˆ‚tâˆ‚â€‹Î¨1â€‹(x,t)+c2â€‹â„âˆ‚tâˆ‚â€‹Î¨2â€‹(x,t)=c1â€‹(âˆ’2mâ„2â€‹âˆ‚x2âˆ‚2â€‹+U(x))Î¨1â€‹(x,t)+c2â€‹(âˆ’2mâ„2â€‹âˆ‚x2âˆ‚2â€‹+U(x))Î¨2â€‹(x,t)=(âˆ’2mâ„2â€‹âˆ‚x2âˆ‚2â€‹+U(x))Î¨(x,t)â€‹
  • The resulting state is not a stationary state.
Î¨(x,t)=c1Ïˆ1(x)eâˆ’iÏ‰1t+c2Ïˆ2(x)eâˆ’iÏ‰2t=eâˆ’iÏ‰1t[c1Ïˆ1(x)+c2Ïˆ2(x)eâˆ’iÏ‰â€²t]\begin{aligned} \Psi(x, t) &=c_{1} \psi_{1}(x) e^{-i \omega_{1} t}+c_{2} \psi_{2}(x) e^{-i \omega_{2} t} \\ &=e^{-i \omega_{1} t}\left[c_{1} \psi_{1}(x)+c_{2} \psi_{2}(x) e^{-i \omega^{\prime} t}\right] \end{aligned}Î¨(x,t)â€‹=c1â€‹Ïˆ1â€‹(x)eâˆ’iÏ‰1â€‹t+c2â€‹Ïˆ2â€‹(x)eâˆ’iÏ‰2â€‹t=eâˆ’iÏ‰1â€‹t[c1â€‹Ïˆ1â€‹(x)+c2â€‹Ïˆ2â€‹(x)eâˆ’iÏ‰â€²t]â€‹

where Ï‰â€²=Ï‰2âˆ’Ï‰1\omega^{\prime}=\omega_{2}-\omega_{1}Ï‰â€²=Ï‰2â€‹âˆ’Ï‰1â€‹.

âˆ£Î¨(x,t)âˆ£2=âˆ£c1Ïˆ1(x)+c2Ïˆ2(x)eâˆ’iÏ‰â€²tâˆ£2|\Psi(x, t)|^{2}=\left|c_{1} \psi_{1}(x)+c_{2} \psi_{2}(x) e^{-i \omega^{\prime} t}\right|^{2}âˆ£Î¨(x,t)âˆ£2=âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹c1â€‹Ïˆ1â€‹(x)+c2â€‹Ïˆ2â€‹(x)eâˆ’iÏ‰â€²tâˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹2

If c1c_{1}c1â€‹ or c2c_{2}c2â€‹ is not zero, this state is dependent of time. If c1c_{1}c1â€‹ or c2c_{2}c2â€‹ is zero, this state is stationary states.

  • If c1=c2=12c_{1}=c_{2}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}c1â€‹=c2â€‹=2â€‹1â€‹
âˆ£Î¨(x,t)âˆ£2=12âˆ£Ïˆ1(x)+Ïˆ2(x)eâˆ’iÏ‰â€²tâˆ£2=12âˆ£Ïˆ1(x)2+Ïˆ2(x)2+2Ïˆ1Ïˆ2(x)cosâ¡(Ï‰â€²t)âˆ£2\begin{aligned}|\Psi(x, t)|^{2} &=\frac{1}{2}\left|\psi_{1}(x)+\psi_{2}(x) e^{-i \omega^{\prime} t}\right|^{2} \\ &=\frac{1}{2}\left|\psi_{1}(x)^{2}+\psi_{2}(x)^{2}+2 \psi_{1} \psi_{2}(x) \cos \left(\omega^{\prime} t\right)\right|^{2} \end{aligned}âˆ£Î¨(x,t)âˆ£2â€‹=21â€‹âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹Ïˆ1â€‹(x)+Ïˆ2â€‹(x)eâˆ’iÏ‰â€²tâˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹2=21â€‹âˆ£âˆ£â€‹Ïˆ1â€‹(x)2+Ïˆ2â€‹(x)2+2Ïˆ1â€‹Ïˆ2â€‹(x)cos(Ï‰â€²t)âˆ£âˆ£â€‹2â€‹

where Ï‰â€²=(E2âˆ’E1)â„\omega^{\prime}=\frac{\left(E_{2}-E_{1}\right)}{\hbar}Ï‰â€²=â„(E2â€‹âˆ’E1â€‹)â€‹

Because of the factor ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘ (ğœ”`ğ‘¡), the probability density vary with time. In this case the time dependence is periodic, with period Ï„=2Ï€Ï‰â€²\tau=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega^{\prime}}Ï„=Ï‰â€²2Ï€â€‹. When the difference of energy of two states is increased, period(or âˆ†ğ‘¡) is decreased.
